p: Developing a safe and effective vaccine against CHIKF—as well as against other reemerging diseases, such as Ebola, Lassa, or Nipah—is important for several reasons. The impact of CHIKF in terms of burden of disease, work and school absenteeism, and other financial costs is particularly high, especially given its formidable epidemic potential. A paradigmatic example is provided by the 2006 epidemic wave that occurred in India, in which more than 1,500,000 cases of CHIKF were reported ( http://www.who.int/denguecontrol/arbo-viral/other_arboviral_chikungunya/en/). Furthermore, the global impact of CHIKV is constantly growing, due to the introduction and spread of the virus into new continents in which it finds optimal conditions for its expansion, including, in some cases, a completely naïve population ( Fig 1). The capacity of CHIKV to adapt to a new mosquito vector has been demonstrated during the Indian Ocean epidemic, when a series of mutations increased fitness for transmission by A. albopictus [ 14, 15], a mosquito that can survive at higher latitudes than A. aegypti [ 16]. This may lead to the occurrence of outbreaks in temperate climates, as seen in Europe [ 8, 9].
